Little Nightmares II is a game built around the tension between smallness and danger, using its unsettling world to create the sensation of navigating a nightmare that is constantly shifting and tightening around you. As Mono, a quiet and vulnerable child armed with nothing but determination and caution, you wake in a forest that feels alive with menace. Every creaking branch, every rustle, every silhouette on the horizon seems to hint at something watching. When you soon meet Six ‚Äî the protagonist of the first game ‚Äî you gain not just a companion, but a silent emotional tether. The game uses their developing partnership to ground the journey through a world that feels both dreamlike and disturbingly real, where everyday places are transformed into hostile labyrinths.

The game‚Äôs environments are its greatest triumph, each one crafted to feel like a distorted reinterpretation of reality. The forest gives way to a ramshackle cabin full of grotesque trophies, then to a sprawling, decaying city swallowed by static. One of the most memorable segments is the school, where the Teacher‚Äôs grotesque elasticity and the violent, doll-like children turn an ordinary classroom into one of the most nightmarish sequences in the entire series. The Pale City that follows is a haunting landscape of warped buildings and shadowy figures transfixed by television screens, evoking themes of apathy, addiction, and the unseen power of the Signal Tower. All these environments share a visual language of decay, loneliness, and warped proportions, creating a dreamscape filled with childhood fears made monstrous.

Puzzle-solving and platforming blend seamlessly with stealth, making progression feel organic rather than segmented. Mono is not helpless; he can wield small weapons, drag objects, and use tools to break through obstacles or defend himself in a limited fashion. These moments of empowerment are brief and always overshadowed by the overwhelming sense that he is still a child in a world far too large and hostile for him. Platforming is often tense and deliberate, with chases that force quick reactions and stealth sections that require precision. While the fixed camera enhances the game‚Äôs cinematic framing, it occasionally complicates depth perception, making some platforming moments feel fragile or unpredictable. Still, the environmental design ensures that nearly every puzzle feels like a natural extension of the world rather than an artificial obstacle.

What makes Little Nightmares II emotionally resonant is how it communicates its story without a single line of spoken dialogue. Mono and Six interact through gestures, glances, and the small ways they help one another across gaps or through danger. These subtle moments carry more weight than scripted conversations in many narrative-heavy games. The story unfolds through implication and symbolism ‚Äî the influence of the Signal Tower, the eeriness of the static-filled televisions, and the way ordinary objects become ominous in the game‚Äôs perspective. This form of environmental storytelling invites interpretation, allowing players to draw meaning from visual cues, the behavior of enemies, and the shift in atmosphere from chapter to chapter.

Audio design plays a huge role in building tension. Ambient sounds echo through empty hallways, distant thumps hint at approaching threats, and the music swells at key moments with a strange blend of melancholy and dread. Even silence is weaponized, used to make every sudden noise more unsettling. Each creature‚Äôs presence is amplified through sound ‚Äî the Teacher‚Äôs scraping, the Mannequins‚Äô twitching movements, the Thin Man‚Äôs staticky interference ‚Äî creating anxiety that lingers long before and after each encounter.

Though the game‚Äôs pacing is tight and deliberate, its short length may leave some players wishing for more time in this horrifying but fascinating world. Its storytelling is intentionally vague, and some narrative threads remain mysterious even at the end, which can feel either enticing or unsatisfying depending on the player‚Äôs preference. At times, the action-oriented sequences ‚Äî especially those involving weapon swings ‚Äî can feel a bit clumsy, momentarily breaking the otherwise smooth immersion. But these are minor cracks in a structure that otherwise holds together powerfully.

Little Nightmares II stands out as one of the most atmospheric and emotionally gripping horror experiences of its kind, blending haunting visuals, tactile tension, and wordless storytelling into a compact but unforgettable journey. It enhances the strengths of its predecessor while expanding the scale and ambition of the world. The result is a dark, surreal adventure that lingers long after the credits, not just for its scares but for the strange, heartbreaking beauty that permeates its nightmarish world.

The first Little Nightmares was mostly about being a little kid in an ominous world of grotesque adults. The sequel takes those themes and amplifies them by fleshing out the adults. What if the adults are being manipulated by ideology through things like television? What if you are destined to become an adult yourself and so part of the problem? What about kids who don't question society's malign influence and so functionally become robots?

If you ever doubt that a side-scrolling, 2.5D game can scare you, "Little Nightmares II" is here to prove you wrong. The atmosphere, the tension and the events of this game can cause you more fear than some of the so-called big horror games. And it doesn't rely on jumpscares. Even the story and lore can be eerie and frightening.
But why am I giving "Little Nightmares II" a thumbs down? Simply because, however, I enjoyed the artistic part, the technical part was a pain. I played the enhanced version (there is another version which I never launched, so I don't know about it), yet I was having some major problems with it.
The first thing that really bugged me was random stuttering. Randomly, you would see the game stutters a bit and loses its smoothness. In some cases, even shaders don't load properly, and you will see objects blink while trying to load. I really don't know the reason, cause they usually happen in more peaceful, empty moments rather than the sequences in which lots of things happen. Changing the video setting doesn't seem to resolve it either. Probably something that is caused by the game engine, which is Unreal Engine.
Another big problem I had with "Little Nightmares II" was the fact that the protagonist would constantly get stuck in environments and objects of the maps. You want to pass through this door? You will get stuck to its frame. You want to crawl under this table? You will get stuck to its legs. Are you passing through this vent? The last part of it, you will get dragged on the ceiling, and your speed would be 1CM per second. This has caused so much pain in chase scenarios where you will get busted, and you will have to try over and over again to finally have a perfect run.
The need to be perfect is also another source of trouble. "Little Nightmares II" consists mostly of two gameplay mechanisms: puzzles and tense scenarios. Puzzles are obvious what they are. And even though they are challenging, they are not impossible, and at worst, you will need a few trial and errors to solve them. But tense scenarios are the scary parts of the games. Those are the moments you are running away or fighting. As I've said, the technical part of "Little Nightmares II" makes these moments quite frustrating.
You have to have a perfect run in order to pass a part of the game. Otherwise, you are stuck in it forever. The sticking into environments makes sure of that. Then there are the fighting scenes, which are unfair as they are, but the environments make it even harder and again, you constantly die and repeat till you finally get a perfect run. One mistake in any of these tense parts means death and checkpoint reload. Again, sticking to environments makes sure you will experience it a lot.
The technical problem persists in checkpoints, too. I know at least two places where checkpoints don't work properly, and the player is forced to reload again in order to proceed. One moment is when you open a door in the school chapter, but the camera doesn't follow you into the new room, yet you have reached the checkpoint. So you are forced to reload, so the camera is finally showing inside the room.
The other is in the hospital, where, after solving a puzzle and getting the key, you will unlock the door. For some reason, the game gets stuck here, without activating the checkpoint, and you are forced to reload the checkpoint, which is before the puzzle, solve the puzzle again and then proceed to the next room. Both of them happened to me twice, since I beat the game twice.
All in all, I can only say that "Little Nightmares II" could have been a great game, but the technical part has ruined the artistic part.

It pains me greatly to give a thumb down to what is a gorgeous and carefully made piece of horror. Especially after a first episode I am very fond of. But the reality is, after finishing the game, I think Little Nightmare II is more trouble than it's worth.

That is, I realize it, saying a lot from the outside looking in, when presented with the incredibly nuanced and creative art direction; an art direction that manages to continuously surprise, even when staying monochrome, cool colors, mostly dark blues, with little kids and big monsters as a main concept. The monsters are grotesque and unnerving. The animations are masterfully done to make the whole cast move as expected and unexpected, depending if we‚Äôre looking at heroes or foes. 

The sound design is also excellent‚Ä¶like genuinely some of the best work I‚Äôve heard in horror games, which is a high praise, since the genre is well known for excelling in that precise department. And the music is ominous, ambient and sometimes melancholic and melodic.

And all that is used in service of a purely visual and auditory narration: no voices, no written words, just animations and actions. The story is also‚Ä¶it‚Äôs good? From what I could gather on one playthrough, it is vague enough that you have to feel the blanks, but still not too abstract to be comprehensible even without words. I‚Äôm sure there is more to dig in‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶that is if you actually want to play and replay the game. The issue being, the game feels like it was not playtested.

I want to make clear that I respect the work of game devs a lot, and I am not saying this in an hyperbolic ‚Äúit‚Äôs a buggy mess, these devs are so lazy these days‚Äù kind of way. For one, because I had a relatively bug free experience: there was one instance where I had to try from the last checkpoint because a script had not spawned the fuse that was required to continue forward; and another time where I swear I pressed the grab trigger but fell through my partners hands and died, having to restart a chase sequence. But other than that, the game is pretty bug free.

The reason the game feels like nobody playtested before launch is simply how unforgiving and frustrating it is to play‚Ä¶ALMOST ALL THE TIME.

It is a staple of the cinematic platformer genre to be a bit stupidly challenging at times. But I liked the most about the first Little Nightmares, or a game like Inside, is that after failing a test once, either because you didn‚Äôt pay attention, or because the game was being cruel in that instance (not a rare occurrence), you generally can pass the sequence the next time around, once you get it. These games also try to balance having tense situations, some slow controls, and giving the player some leeway to get out of it without dying. Because dying resets the tension to zero. And dying several times in a row transforms tension and thrill into frustration, and potentially anger (and then into sadness, and then the dark side).

Little Nightmares 2, on the other hand, does not give a sh*t about tension.

The game is of course filled to the brim with unwinnable situations on the first try; which, as I said, is par for the course in that genre; but they are also hardly passable on subsequent attempts. 

At first glance, you might want to point to the controls. The combat ‚Äúsystem‚Äù consists in placing your character carefully next to a usable pipe, hammer or axe, then letting the grab animation playing out for an eternity, then timing the swing of the thing that moves with the velocity of a slug taking a sh*t, and doing all this without the possibility of dodging. In the same vein, jumps are limp, delayed, full of inertia, as in they require a bit of a start up if you don‚Äôt want to jump where you are, instead of where you want to go. There is also a sprint that, combined with the crouch, can turn into a slide, although I struggled to get that consistently (let‚Äôs call it skill issue); and you can finally grab and climb. And you, of course, die in one shot. There is no surviving an attack in Little Nightmare 2.

Now the issue isn‚Äôt necessarily in the sluggishness of the controls themselves: Inside and Little Nightmares are not exactly precision platformers and they make it work. No, the issue is the absurdity of the timings that the game demands in conjunction with these controls. 

The combat system is all well and good at first, when it comes to just sneaking behind a porcelain kid and smashing its head off with a clean swing from behind. But when two, three kids in a row, running towards you, are starting to pile up during a chase sequence, the slow grab animation, and the extra slow build up animation to the swing are merciless, even when you actually understand the attack timing (YES, I KNOW YOU NEED TO PRESS A WHEN THEY START SCREAMING!). That is not even talking about the tiny spider type enemies that move fast as sh*t, granted with a huge pause before attacking, but that made for one of the worst combat situations of the whole game when you have to deal with two of them at the same time.

There is also a torch mechanic later, that I won‚Äôt spoil, where the game expects you to point properly in the right direction in sync with moving and it‚Äôs‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just such a pain.

As for the movements, you are very regularly thrown into chase or stealth sequences where the beauty of the detailed animations becomes the bane of your existence, because all these extra frames are just more opportunity to slow you down, when the game wants you to PICK-UP-THE-PACE-YOU-SNAIL. And these moments are not necessarily super hard, but they are really testing the limits of the reactivity you can have with these controls, generally ending up with 2 to 5 deaths, pretty much destroying any sense of pacing and engagement with the actual horrific situation.

And I‚Äôm not even mad, as in, I never threw my controller (I mean, my controller is a Steam Deck so I‚Äôd be hard pressed to throw it anyway) or really shook my fist in the air. It is just‚Ä¶sad. It genuinely bums me out that there isn‚Äôt a ‚Äústory‚Äù mode where the game would be more lenient with the timing and maybe just gets rid of half the enemies in the combat situations that don‚Äôt bring anything but frustration. That I‚Äôm stuck in a reality where this cool piece of visual horror storytelling, with some cool puzzles and great atmosphere is stuck between rage baits. This sequel to a game I really loved looks and sounds amazing, and was obviously made by talented people who put great care into making it. And I‚Äôm just heart broken they didn‚Äôt see they were ruining a large portion of it with a challenge that does not work with what the controls are.

‚Ä¶that is if you actually want to play and replay the game. The issue being, the game feels like it was not playtested.

I want to make clear that I respect the work of game devs a lot, and I am not saying this in an hyperbolic ‚Äúit‚Äôs a buggy mess, these devs are so lazy these days‚Äù kind of way. For one, because I had a relatively bug free experience: there was one instance where I had to try from the last checkpoint because a script had not spawned the fuse that was required to continue forward; and another time where I swear I pressed the grab trigger but fell through my partners hands and died, having to restart a chase sequence. The reason the game feels like nobody playtested before launch is simply how unforgiving and frustrating it is to play‚Ä¶ALMOST ALL THE TIME.

It is a staple of the cinematic platformer genre to be a bit stupidly challenging at times. But I liked the most about the first Little Nightmares, or a game like Inside, is that after failing a test once, either because you didn‚Äôt pay attention, or because the game was being cruel in that instance (not a rare occurrence), you generally can pass the sequence the next time around, once you get it. These games also try to balance having tense situations, some slow controls, and giving the player some leeway to get out of it without dying. Because dying resets the tension to zero. And dying several times in a row transforms tension and thrill into frustration, and potentially anger (and then into sadness, and then the dark side).

Little Nightmares 2, on the other hand, does not give a sh*t about tension.

The game is of course filled to the brim with unwinnable situations on the first try; which, as I said, is par for the course in that genre; but they are also hardly passable on subsequent attempts. 

At first glance, you might want to point to the controls. The combat ‚Äúsystem‚Äù consists in placing your character carefully next to a usable pipe, hammer or axe, then letting the grab animation playing out for an eternity, then timing the swing of the thing that moves with the velocity of a slug taking a sh*t, and doing all this without the possibility of dodging. In the same vein, jumps are limp, delayed, full of inertia, as in they require a bit of a start up if you don‚Äôt want to jump where you are, instead of where you want to go. There is also a sprint that, combined with the crouch, can turn into a slide, although I struggled to get that consistently (let‚Äôs call it skill issue); and you can finally grab and climb. And you, of course, die in one shot. There is no surviving an attack in Little Nightmare 2.

Now the issue isn‚Äôt necessarily in the sluggishness of the controls themselves: Inside and Little Nightmares are not exactly precision platformers and they make it work. No, the issue is the absurdity of the timings that the game demands in conjunction with these controls. 

The combat system is all well and good at first, when it comes to just sneaking behind a porcelain kid and smashing its head off with a clean swing from behind. But when two, three kids in a row, running towards you, are starting to pile up during a chase sequence, the slow grab animation, and the extra slow build up animation to the swing are merciless, even when you actually understand the attack timing (YES, I KNOW YOU NEED TO PRESS A WHEN THEY START SCREAMING!). That is not even talking about the tiny spider type enemies that move fast as sh*t, granted with a huge pause before attacking, but that made for one of the worst combat situations of the whole game when you have to deal with two of them at the same time.

There is also a torch mechanic later, that I won‚Äôt spoil, where the game expects you to point properly in the right direction in sync with moving and it‚Äôs‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just such a pain.

As for the movements, you are very regularly thrown into chase or stealth sequences where the beauty of the detailed animations becomes the bane of your existence, because all these extra frames are just more opportunity to slow you down, when the game wants you to PICK-UP-THE-PACE-YOU-SNAIL. And these moments are not necessarily super hard, but they are really testing the limits of the reactivity you can have with these controls, generally ending up with 2 to 5 deaths, pretty much destroying any sense of pacing and engagement with the actual horrific situation.

And I‚Äôm not even mad, as in, I never threw my controller (I mean, my controller is a Steam Deck so I‚Äôd be hard pressed to throw it anyway) or really shook my fist in the air. It is just‚Ä¶sad. It genuinely bums me out that there isn‚Äôt a ‚Äústory‚Äù mode where the game would be more lenient with the timing and maybe just gets rid of half the enemies in the combat situations that don‚Äôt bring anything but frustration. That I‚Äôm stuck in a reality where this cool piece of visual horror storytelling, with some cool puzzles and great atmosphere is stuck between rage baits. This sequel to a game I really loved looks and sounds amazing, and was obviously made by talented people who put great care into making it. And I‚Äôm just heart broken they didn‚Äôt see they were ruining a large portion of it with a challenge that does not work with what the controls are.

One mistake in any of these tense parts means death and checkpoint reload. Again, sticking to environments makes sure you will experience it a lot.

Little Nightmares 2, on the other hand, does not give a sh*t about tension.

The game is of course filled to the brim with unwinnable situations on the first try; which, as I said, is par for the course in that genre; but they are also hardly passable on subsequent attempts. 

At first glance, you might want to point to the controls. The combat ‚Äúsystem‚Äù consists in placing your character carefully next to a usable pipe, hammer or axe, then letting the grab animation playing out for an eternity, then timing the swing of the thing that moves with the velocity of a slug taking a sh*t, and doing all this without the possibility of dodging. In the same vein, jumps are limp, delayed, full of inertia, as in they require a bit of a start up if you don‚Äôt want to jump where you are, instead of where you want to go. There is also a sprint that, combined with the crouch, can turn into a slide, although I struggled to get that consistently (let‚Äôs call it skill issue); and you can finally grab and climb. And you, of course, die in one shot. There is no surviving an attack in Little Nightmare 2.

Now the issue isn‚Äôt necessarily in the sluggishness of the controls themselves: Inside and Little Nightmares are not exactly precision platformers and they make it work. No, the issue is the absurdity of the timings that the game demands in conjunction with these controls. 

The combat system is all well and good at first, when it comes to just sneaking behind a porcelain kid and smashing its head off with a clean swing from behind. But when two, three kids in a row, running towards you, are starting to pile up during a chase sequence, the slow grab animation, and the extra slow build up animation to the swing are merciless, even when you actually understand the attack timing (YES, I KNOW YOU NEED TO PRESS A WHEN THEY START SCREAMING!). That is not even talking about the tiny spider type enemies that move fast as sh*t, granted with a huge pause before attacking, but that made for one of the worst combat situations of the whole game when you have to deal with two of them at the same time.

There is also a torch mechanic later, that I won‚Äôt spoil, where the game expects you to point properly in the right direction in sync with moving and it‚Äôs‚Ä¶it‚Äôs just such a pain.

As for the movements, you are very regularly thrown into chase or stealth sequences where the beauty of the detailed animations becomes the bane of your existence, because all these extra frames are just more opportunity to slow you down, when the game wants you to PICK-UP-THE-PACE-YOU-SNAIL. And these moments are not necessarily super hard, but they are really testing the limits of the reactivity you can have with these controls, generally ending up with 2 to 5 deaths, pretty much destroying any sense of pacing and engagement with the actual horrific situation.

And I‚Äôm not even mad, as in, I never threw my controller (I mean, my controller is a Steam Deck so I‚Äôd be hard pressed to throw it anyway) or really shook my fist in the air. It is just‚Ä¶sad. It genuinely bums me out that there isn‚Äôt a ‚Äústory‚Äù mode where the game would be more lenient with the timing and maybe just gets rid of half the enemies in the combat situations that don‚Äôt bring anything but frustration. That I‚Äôm stuck in a reality where this cool piece of visual horror storytelling, with some cool puzzles and great atmosphere is stuck between rage baits. This sequel to a game I really loved looks and sounds amazing, and was obviously made by talented people who put great care into making it. And I‚Äôm just heart broken they didn‚Äôt see they were ruining a large portion of it with a challenge that does not work with what the controls are.

If you ever doubt that a side-scrolling, 2.5D game can scare you, "Little Nightmares II" is here to prove you wrong. The atmosphere, the tension and the events of this game can cause you more fear than some of the so-called big horror games. And it doesn't rely on jumpscares. Even the story and lore can be eerie and frightening.
But why am I giving "Little Nightmares II" a thumbs down? Simply because, however, I enjoyed the artistic part, the technical part was a pain. I played the enhanced version (there is another version which I never launched, so I don't know about it), yet I was having some major problems with it.
The first thing that really bugged me was random stuttering. Randomly, you would see the game stutters a bit and loses its smoothness. In some cases, even shaders don't load properly, and you will see objects blink while trying to load. I really don't know the reason, cause they usually happen in more peaceful, empty moments rather than the sequences in which lots of things happen. Changing the video setting doesn't seem to resolve it either. Probably something that is caused by the game engine, which is Unreal Engine.
Another big problem I had with "Little Nightmares II" was the fact that the protagonist would constantly get stuck in environments and objects of the maps. You want to pass through this door? You will get stuck to its frame. You want to crawl under this table? You will get stuck to its legs. Are you passing through this vent? The last part of it, you will get dragged on the ceiling, and your speed would be 1CM per second. This has caused so much pain in chase scenarios where you will get busted, and you will have to try over and over again to finally have a perfect run.
The need to be perfect is also another source of trouble. "Little Nightmares II" consists mostly of two gameplay mechanisms: puzzles and tense scenarios. Puzzles are obvious what they are. And even though they are challenging, they are not impossible, and at worst, you will need a few trial and errors to solve them. But tense scenarios are the scary parts of the games. Those are the moments you are running away or fighting. As I've said, the technical part of "Little Nightmares II" makes these moments quite frustrating.
You have to have a perfect run in order to pass a part of the game. Otherwise, you are stuck in it forever. The sticking into environments makes sure of that. Then there are the fighting scenes, which are unfair as they are, but the environments make it even harder and again, you constantly die and repeat till you finally get a perfect run. One mistake in any of these tense parts means death and checkpoint reload. Again, sticking to environments makes sure you will experience it a lot.
The technical problem persists in checkpoints, too. I know at least two places where checkpoints don't work properly, and the player is forced to reload again in order to proceed. One moment is when you open a door in the school chapter, but the camera doesn't follow you into the new room, yet you have reached the checkpoint. So you are forced to reload, so the camera is finally showing inside the room.
The other is in the hospital, where, after solving a puzzle and getting the key, you will unlock the door. For some reason, the game gets stuck here, without activating the checkpoint, and you are forced to reload the checkpoint, which is before the puzzle, solve the puzzle again and then proceed to the next room. Both of them happened to me twice, since I beat the game twice.
All in all, I can only say that "Little Nightmares II" could have been a great game, but the technical part has ruined the artistic part.
